Barbarea vulgaris R.Br.
( Brassicaceae ) Glucosinolate hydrolysis
Turnover
1,3-Oxazolidine-2-thione 1,3-Oxazolidin-2-one
Nitrile
Thioamide

paragraph.emphasis: A B S T R A C T

subSection.paragraph:
Glucosinolates are found in plants of the order Brassicales and hydrolyzed to different breakdown products, particularly after tissue damage. In
Barbarea vulgaris R.Br.
( Brassicaceae ), the dominant glucosinolate in the investigated “G-type” is glucobarbarin, ( S )-2-hydroxy-2-phenylethylglucosinolate. Formation of the nitrile from glucobarbarin was observed in vitro , while a previously suggested thioamide (synonym thionamide) was not confirmed. Resedine (5-phenyl-1,3-oxazolidin-2-one) was detected after glucobarbarin hydrolysis in crushed
B. vulgaris
leaves and siliques, but not in intact parts. The abundance increased for several hours after completion of hydrolysis. The corresponding 1,3- oxazolidine-2-thione (OAT), with the common name barbarin, was also formed, and appeared to be the precursor of resedine. Addition of each of two non-endogenous OATs, ( S )-5-ethyl-5-methylOAT and ( R )-5-vinylOAT ( R -goitrin), to a leaf homogenate resulted in formation of the corresponding 1,3- oxazolidin-2-ones (OAOs), confirming the metabolic connection of OAT to OAO. Formation of OAOs was inhibited by prior brief heating of the homogenate, suggesting enzyme involvement. We suggest the conversion of OATs to OAOs to be catalyzed by an enzyme (“oxazolidinethionase”) responsible for turnover of OAT formed in intact plants. Resedine had been reported as an alkaloid from another species -
Reseda luteola
L. ( Resedaceae ) - naturally containing the glucosinolate glucobarbarin. However, resedine was not detected in intact
R. luteola
plants, but formed after tissue damage. The formation of resedine in two families suggests a broad distribution of putative OATases in the Brassicales ; potentially involved in glucosinolate turnover that needs myrosinase activity as the committed step. In agreement with the proposed function of OATase, several candidate genes for myrosinases in glucosinolate turnover in intact plants were discovered in the
B. vulgaris
genome. We also suggest that biotechnological conversion of OATs to OAOs might improve the nutritional value of Brassicales protein. HPLC-MS/MS methods for detection of these glucobarbarin products are described.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Three heterocyclic ring systems found in Brassicales metabolites: 1,3- oxazolidine-2-thione (OAT), 1,3-thiazolidin-2-one (TAO), 1,3-oxazolidin-2-one (OAO), and their parent heterocyclic frames. Substituted OAT and TAO are known glucosinolate degradation products. In this paper, biochemical conversion of 5-substituted OATs into 5-substituted OAOs is suggested.

subSection.paragraph: From non-enzymatic breakdown of glucobarbarin and progoitrin catalyzed by high concentrations of ferrous salts, thioamides were reported in high yields, on the base of limited analytical evidence ( Austin et al., 1968a ; b). A later report provided circumstantial evidence (UV-spectrum of a minor chromatographic peak) for the formation of low levels of the thioamide from epiglucobarbarin at similar high ferrous ion conditions, and discussed the possibility of ferrous ion catalyzed turnover of b -hydroxyalkyl glucosinolates in biological material ( Bellostas et al., 2008 ).

In order to better understand ecological functions of glucobarbarin in our main experimental plant
B. vulgaris
, we set out to investigate its breakdown products in vitro as well as in vivo . Our initial objective was to determine the biochemical hydrolysis products from glucobarbarin, expected to be barbarin, 3-hydroxy- 3-phenylpropanenitrile ( 4 ) and possibly the related thioamide (hypothetic “ 5 ”). However, an unexpected product with the same nominal mass as a potential thioamide fragment appeared, so an additional goal was to identify this OAO product and test for an enzymatic formation from the corresponding OAT. We here report lack of formation of a thioamide, scarce formation of the nitrile, and unexpected formation of OAOs via OATs catalyzed by a heat sensitive factor in glucobarbarin-containing plants. The formation of the OAO, resedine ( 3 ), is characterized and the connection to glucosinolate turnover investigated.

heading.emphasis: 2.1. Identi fi cation of the nitrile from glucobarbarin hydrolysis

subSection.paragraph: One glucobarbarin product, barbarin ( 2 ), was already at hand, and ion trap HPLC-MS was optimized for detection in the relevant mass range for glucobarbarin products (Section 3.6). In order to obtain the nitrile from glucobarbarin, the isolated glucosinolate was subjected to myrosinase-catalyzed hydrolysis in a well-defined in vitro system at pH 5 in the presence and absence of 2.5 mM of a ferrous salt, FeSO 4 . As expected, both barbarin and a product with mass spectrum matching the expected nitrile ( 4 ) were formed at both conditions, with barbarin dominating without added FeSO 4 and the nitrile 4 dominating with added FeSO 4 ( Fig. 3 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Reactions of glucobarbarin investigated in this paper. A. Biochemical conversion of glucobarbarin into barbarin via an unstable isothiocyanate, and the further conversion to resedine catalyzed by a heat-sensitive factor. The heat-sensitive factor is suggested to be a plant enzyme, for which we suggest the common name oxazolidinethionase (OATase). Turnover is initiated by myrosinase (MYR). Systematic names of breakdown products are: 5-phenyl-1,3-oxazolidine-2-thione (barbarin) and 5-phenyl-1,3-oxazolidin-2-thione (without “e” before last hyphen) (resedine). B. An alternative outcome of MYR-catalyzed hydrolysis, in the presence of ferrous ion. C. Hypothetic, non-enzymatic conversion of glucobarbarin to a thioamide. This reaction had been suggested in the literature but was not confirmed here.

subSection.paragraph: A previously suggested thioamide (hypothetic “ 5 ”) was searched for but not detected ( Fig. 3 ). Resedine ( 3 ) and an amide ( 8 ), discussed below, were not detected either. The ion trap MS of 4 was dominated by the sodium adduct and a proton adduct after loss of water, while the proton adduct itself was minor ( Fig. 4a ). By comparison with two related model compounds, we could confirm that such loss of water was predictable for 4 because of the b -position of the hydroxyl group. The phenolic isomer 6 lost water to a much lower extent in ion trap MS ( Fig. 4b ), while association of both hydroxyl substitutions ( 7 ) led to complete loss of water from the proton adduct due to the activating effect of the p -hydroxyl group ( Fig. 4c ). Using a higher resolution QqToF MS, we confirmed the identity of 4 (found: 130.0649 [M-H 2 OþH] þ , calculated for C 9 H 8 N þ : 130.0651). As 1 was precursor and ferrous salts are well known to stimulate nitrile formation from glucosinolate hydrolysis, the structure of product 4 was ascertained as 4 (3-hydroxy-3- phenylpropanenitrile).

paragraph.emphasis: 2.2. Amide but no thioamide detected from in vitro, non-enzymatic glucobarbarin breakdown with a ferrous salt

subSection.paragraph: We were intrigued by the historical report of 3-hydroxy-3- phenylpropanethioamide (hypothetic “ 5 ”) from glucobarbarin at high ferrous salt concentrations ( Austin et al., 1968a ) and a tentative later confirmation ( Bellostas et al., 2008 ). In an attempt to obtain a reference, the reported procedure ( Austin et al., 1968a ) was repeated with slight modifications (Section 3.5). Extensive glucobarbarin degradation (92%) after incubation at 15 mM with 150 mM ferrous ammonium sulfate was confirmed by HPLC-analysis ( Fig. 5A ). However, product analysis by HPLC-DAD did not reveal any peak matching the suggested thioamide with ƛ max at 267 nm ( Austin et al., 1968a ). After extraction with ethyl acetate, the two major products absorbing at 210 nm ( Fig. 5B ) were isolated by HPLC and identified as 3-hydroxy-3-phenylpropanamide ( 8 , tentative) and the nitrile 4 by ion trap HPLC-MS/MS and HPLC-QqToF-MS. Formed along with a nitrile, the amide 8 was considered a reasonable structure, as it can be likened to hydrated nitrile. In the ion trap with eluents doped with NaCl, the sodium adduct was dominant ( Fig. 5C ). The suggested identity was supported by QqToF-MS (found: 166.0866 [MþH] þ , calculated for 8 , [C 9 H 12 O 2 N] þ : 166.0863). Fragmentation of the sodium adduct in ion trap MS supported the identity, as the major loss of 59 amu matched loss of acetamide, leaving an ion with the composition as a sodium adduct of benzaldehyde ( m / z 129). The hydrogen adduct detected in QqToF-MS fragmented differently, with major loss of 60 amu (acetic acid) leaving a fragment matching the composition of phenylmethaniminium ion (found: 106.0653 [M-acetic acidþH] þ , calculated for C 7 H 8 N þ : 106.0651). We find acid-catalyzed rearrangement with loss of acetic acid in agreement with the proposed structure, 8 . Searching the data files after ion trap HPLC-MS of the entire ethyl acetate extract and six isolated peaks did not reveal any sign of the presence of the suggested thioamide “ 5 ”. Specifically, we searched for expected m / z values of hypothetic “ 5 ”: 182 [MþH] þ or 204 [MþNa] þ or 164 [M-H 2 OþH] þ . This expected MS was based on experience with related metabolites 4 , 6 , 7 and 8 ( Figs. 4 and 5 ).

Observation of an amide ( 8 ) but no thioamide (“ 5 ”) could not be explained by contamination with the reagents described later, catalyzing conversion of the thiocarbonyl functional group in OATs to the carbonyl functional group in OAOs. This could be firmly concluded for logistic reasons (Section 3.5).

paragraph.emphasis: 2.3. Resedine formed after autolysis in Reseda , Barbarea and

subSection.paragraph:
The spontaneous hydrolysis of glucosinolates in crushed Brassicales plant material is termed autolysis. As the profile of non-OAT glucobarbarin hydrolysis products in green parts of
B. vulgaris
was completely unknown, we first investigated the autolysis of
B. vulgari
s foliage (upper leaves of flowering plants of the ‘G-type’ of this species, which is rich in glucobarbarin) (Agerbirk et al., 2015). As expected, the OAT barbarin ( 2 ) was a major autolysis product, while the nitrile ( 4 ) was not detected or at trace levels. Despite the complex nature of
B. vulgaris
metabolite extracts ( Dalby-Brown et al., 2011 ; Khakimov et al., 2016 ), the chromatograms contained only few major peaks ( Fig. 6 ), probably because the ion trap was targeted at low m / z values (target m / z 180), in practice resulting in a quasi-normal distribution of detected m / z values centered around the target and leaving m / z values above ca. 300 undetected (Section 3.6). With these ion trap settings, we noticed a medium intensity peak with MS2 similar to that of barbarin. As explained below, the metabolite in this peak was shown to be resedine ( 3 ).

Resedine formation in
B. vulgaris
was detected in plant parts sampled from the investigated 2nd year plants over a period of three months, in leaves as well as in siliques. Resedine formation was also observed in dry seeds homogenized in water, and in seedlings ( Table 1 ). The peak was much smaller than the barbarin peak soon after complete glucosinolate hydrolysis (at 0.5 h after crushing the plant part in a mortar), but increased in intensity over time ( Fig. 6A ). In extracts of intact foliage, resedine was not detected, while barbarin was detected at much reduced levels (around 5% of levels after intended complete autolysis), as expected for an artifact from ‘partial autolysis during handling and extraction’.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 3. Chromatograms (ion trap HPLC-MS) of glucobarbarin degradation products formed in the presence of myrosinase (MYR) and absence (A) or presence (B) of 2.5 mM FeSO 4 . Extracted ion chromatograms (EIC) are shown, measuring relevant m / z values (±0.5) as follows: 2 , 202, 180, 146, 120; 4 , 170, 148, 130; hypothetic “ 5 ”, 204 [MþNa] þ , 182 [MþH] þ , 164 [M-H OþH] þ . Scales for 4 and hypothetic “ 5 ” are identical, 2 while the scale for 2 is ten-fold as condensed to account for observed higher sensitivity for 2 . Unidentified trace peaks x1 ( m / z 181) and x2 ( m / z 164 but not 204 or 182) did not agree with expected MS of hypothetic “ 5 ” or resedine ( 3 ).

Fig. 4. Ion trap mass spectra of the nitrile 4 (A) derived from glucobarbarin as well as two related model compounds, 3-(4-hydroxyphenyl)propanenitrile ( 6 ) (B) and 3- hydroxy-3-(4-hydroxyphenyl)propanenitrile ( 7 ) (C), for comparison of MS2 fragmentation.

subSection.paragraph:
The ion trap mass spectrum of barbarin is characteristic, with major losses of CSO and H 2 S ( Fig. 6C ). The metabolite proving to be resedine showed the same fragments as barbarin, whereas the molecular ions [MþH] þ and [MþNa] þ had m / z values 16 amu lower than those of barbarin ( Fig. 6D ). It seemed obvious that this metabolite was related to barbarin, but with the sulfur replaced by oxygen resulting in losses of CO 2 and H 2 O rather than CSO and H 2 S. Indeed, the UV band from C=S at 242 nm in barbarin was missing (Supplementary Fig. 1 ). For NMR analysis, resedine was isolated by HPLC from foliage autolyzed for 24 h (Supplementary Fig. 2 ). The proton NMR spectrum, with a complex cluster of resonances from the phenyl group in the 7.37‾7.44 ppm interval, and three coupled signals of H5 (5.64 ppm, apparent t), H4a (3.98 ppm, apparent dt) and H4b (3.54, ddd) was in excellent agreement with literature spectra ( Sheng et al., 2017 ; Lutfullin et al., 1976 ). First order analysis was not possible, but PERCH analysis confirmed the interpretation and provided accurate chemical shifts and coupling constant values (Supplementary Fig. 3 ). The QqToF-MS confirmed also the interpretations above of MS2 fragmentation, with major losses of H 2 O and CO 2 from the proton adduct. The ion trap HPLC-MS of resedine also agreed with a synthetic specimen prepared from 2 at oxidizing conditions, using H 2 O
2 in
a procedure simplified and scaled down from the literature (Section 3.12).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 5. Major products of ferrous ion-catalyzed degradation of glucobarbarin ( 1 ). A, reaction scheme; B,HPLC of products with UV detection at 210 nm; C, ion trap MS and MS2 spectra of the tentatively identified amide 8 , isolated from the HPLC-separation in B.

subSection.paragraph:
Literature search revealed that 3 was a known natural product reported as an alkaloid from
R. luteola
and hence named resedine ( Lutfullin et al., 1976 ). Extraction and analysis of that plant species showed that resedine was not detectable in intact foliage, but was a medium-abundance peak after autolysis ( Fig. 6B , Table 1 ). We also searched old data files ( Agerbirk et al., 2014 ) from analysis of autolysis products of glucobarbarin in watercress,
N. of fi cinale
, and observed a peak with the four characteristic ions of resedine, reasonable tR compared to barbarin, and lacking in extracts without autolysis (Supplementary Fig. 4 ). We concluded that resedine is formed after autolysis, possibly as a downstream glucobarbarin product ( Fig. 6 AþB ), in at least three Brassicales species, but is not a major metabolite in intact tissue of any of the species.

paragraph.emphasis: 2.4. Only traces of nitrile and no amide or thioamide as autolysis product

subSection.paragraph:
The nitrile, detected with certainty from in vitro breakdown of glucobarbarin by myrosinase as well as with a ferrous salt, was not detected with certainty in any of our autolysis experiments. The low amounts reported in Table 1 are maximum estimates calculated from minor or trace peaks, of which none were confirmed by MS2. However, the spectrum of putative 4 from seedlings showed good resemblance with the reference spectrum. As some plants convert nitriles into amides enzymatically ( Agerbirk et al., 2007 ), we also searched the autolysis extracts for the corresponding amide 8 . A trace was detected in all analyzed samples after autolysis, but an equally abundant trace was also detected in many samples before autolysis and in a species (
Reseda odorata
L.) not containing glucobarbarin. The identity of the putative 8 could not be ascertained by MS 2 in any sample due to very low levels. Hence, we concluded that the amide 8 , if present at all, was a low level constituent not derived from glucobarbarin breakdown during autolysis.

Inspired by the in vitro stimulation of nitrile formation by a ferrous salt (Section 2.1.), an equivalent level of FeSO 4 was added to a leaf before homogenization ( Table 1 ). However, a slight possible increase of nitrile formation in one experiment was far less than in the in vitro experiment, suggesting that other binding sites competed for ferrous ion in the homogenate.

In systematic attempts to detect the historically claimed thioamide from glucobarbarin degradation, we searched chromatograms of autolysis samples with and without added ferrous salt for the expected m / z values of hypothetic “ 5 ”. However, no candidate peak was found, except that the expected loss-of-water fragment mass ( m / z 164) matched resedine ( 3 ) discussed above. We also analyzed samples with HPLC-DAD and searched manually UV traces at 267 nm for peaks with the reported UV spectrum, with a maximum at 267 nm ( Austin et al., 1968a ), but found no candidate peaks. In general, HPLC-DAD chromatograms were complex, and 4 and to some extent 3 were disturbed by coeluting peaks (Supplementary Fig. 2 ). We concluded that no conclusive evidence for a thioamide (“ 5 ”) formed from glucobarbarin has ever been reported, despite two claims, and formation of “ 5 ” could not be confirmed despite systematic attempts (Section 2.2).

The low levels of nitrile product observed would suggest that nitrile specifier proteins are not of major importance in upper leaves, siliques and seeds of
B. vulgaris ( Kissen and Bones, 2009 )
. Lack of an effect of an added ferrous salt supports this conclusion ( Kong et al., 2012 ). As specifier proteins are organ specific, this conclusion cannot be generalized to all organs, and seedlings, roots and first years plants should be tested separately (Wittstock et al., 2016a; b). Formation after induction is also a possibility; nitriles and amides corresponding to products of phenethylglucosinolate (similar to glucobarbarin, but lacking the b -hydroxy group) were detected after induction with CuCl
2 in
B. vulgaris ( Pedras et al., 2015 )
. However, the glucosinolate profile of the investigated
B. vulgaris
accession was not reported, and the tissues were extracted directly without preceding autolysis, so direct comparison with the present work is not possible.

paragraph.emphasis: 2.5. Time course and heat sensitivity of formation of resedine in crushed tissue

subSection.paragraph: The time course of formation of resedine was further investigated, hoping that it would shed light on the mechanism of formation during autolysis. When varying the autolysis time for leaves and siliques, a quasi-linear formation of resedine was observed over 3 h or more, suggesting that any needed additional reactant (other than barbarin) was continuously available in homogenized tissue ( Fig. 7A ). These experiments were carried out with individual samples of leaves or siliques, and without buffer addition. As the individual samples could vary in initial glucobarbarin concentration, the appearance of resedine could only be defined in relative terms. From the long quasi-linear phase in the undiluted homogenates, we anticipate that any co-reactant would be a simple, abundant molecule like H 2 O or O 2 . A hydrolysis would be the simplest reaction class, but an oxidative reaction is also a possibility.

tableNote.paragraph:
g Glucosinolates in
R. odorata
did not include glucobarbarin. The main glucosinolate, after desulfation, showed tR almost as desulfo indol-3-ylmethylglucosinolate and an m / z value of 514 [MþNa] þ and 492 [MþH] þ , and fragments at m / z 330 and 184. The latter fragments were also seen in MS2 of the proton adduct, as expected for loss of anhydroglucose ( m / z 330, [M-162 þ H] þ ) and further loss of anhydrorhamnose ( m / z 184, [M-162-146 þ H] þ ). All of this would be in accordance with dominance of o -rhamnosyloxybenzylglucosinolate as expected for the species ( Olsen and SØrensen, 1979 ).

subSection.paragraph: It is well established that OATs are unstable at very high temperature, as found in GC instruments ( Lutfullin et al., 1976 ; Radulovic et al., 2017 ). Rearrangement to TAOs was reported at GC conditions. Hence, in the experimental design, it was critical that all samples received the same heat treatment, but at different time after homogenization. Clearly, the factor determining the amount of resedine formed was not related to heat energy received, but to the reaction time allowed before heating was carried out. TAOs are detectable at our conditions (Agerbirk and Olsen, 2015), but were not observed, confirming that barbarin was stable at the moderate temperatures used here (100 ǫC and below).

paragraph.emphasis: 2.6. Detection of heat-sensitive OATase acting on spiked OATs in B.

subSection.paragraph: Addition of the OAT 9 did result in appreciable accumulation of the corresponding OAO 10 ( Fig. 9AþE ), while this OAO was not seen in a control without the added OAT ( Fig. 9BþF ). In contrast, a briefly heated homogenate essentially did not catalyze conversion of added 9 to 10 ( Fig. 9CþG ). As a control for substrate impurities or general non-enzymatic formation of OAOs, 9 was incubated in parallel with a pH 5 buffer. A tiny OAO peak detected in the heated controls with homogenates was also observed in the heated buffer controls, apparently due to a minor contamination of the OAT substrate used for spiking ( Fig. 9DþH ).

The other tested OAT was ( R )-goitrin ( 11 ) with the systematic name ( R )-5-vinylOAT. Addition of ( R )-goitrin resulted in a minor but distinct peak of the corresponding OAO 12 (Supplementary Fig. 5 ). The MS of the peak matched the MS of an authentic reference (Section 3.13) when background was taken into account (Supplementary Fig. 5 ). The product peak ( 12 ) was confirmed to be essentially absent from a control of the substrate 11 incubated with pH 5 buffer, in accordance with the product peak being due to enzymatic conversion in the plant material. With this substrate ( 11 ) and product ( 12 ), peak intensities were about fivefold lower than seen for 9 and 10 , despite the OATs 9 and 11 being added at similar concentration. The apparent lower sensitivity was a logical consequence of the lowered Mr , considering the quite narrow focusing of the ion trap. Indeed, UV detection (Supplementary Fig. 6 ) confirmed that both OATs were present at high levels (calculated as ca. 10 mM), comparable to the endogenous level of barbarin. So there was no evidence for different reaction rates for the two tested OATs, 9 vs 11 . As a further control of sufficient access of the ( R )- goitrin spike, addition of the glucosinolate precursor of ( R )-goitrin, epiprogoitrin, resulted in formation of goitrin in situ (Supplementary Fig. 6 ) and also of a minor peak of the corresponding OAO, 12 .

We concluded that a heat sensitive factor in
B. vulgaris
homogenates converts several OATs ( 2 , 9 and 11 ) into corresponding OAOs ( 3 , 10 and 12 ). As autolysis was going on in the homogenate before addition of the spike, and OATase activity was expected to slow down due to the experimental dilution, there was no reason to believe that formation of resedine would be significantly inhibited by one or more added OATs. Test for conversion of ( R )-goitrin ( 11 ) was also relevant from an applied perspective, as 11 is formed from epiprogoitrin in the potential industrial crop
Crambe abyssinica Hochst. ex R. E. Fries
( Brassicaceae ) ( Lazzeri et al., 1994 ). The ( S )- goitrin enantiomer was not tested in this work. An OATase enzyme capable of removing the thione functionality of ( S )-goitrin would seem to have potential in improving the nutritional value of rapeseed (
Brassica napus
) protein that suffer from ( S )-goitrin and progoitrin contamination ( Agerbirk et al., 2014 ; Felker et al., 2016 ; Radulovic et al., 2017 ). Clearly, the natural enantiomer of goitrin in
Brassica napus
should be used for testing relevant plants for a suitable OATase.

paragraph.emphasis: 2.7. Candidate genes for turnover of glucosinolates in intact B.

subSection.paragraph:
The biological function of putative OATase could be the observed: turnover of OATs after autolysis. However, OATase could also be involved in turnover of OAT after glucosinolate turnover in intact plants ( Fig. 2A ). The very slow formation of resedine, indicating a rather low OATase activity (initial rate around 0.2‾2 nkat/g fresh wt. estimated from data behind Fig. 7A ), was in contrast to the fast first step in glucobarbarin hydrolysis during autolysis. Hence, we decided to search for candidate genes for initiation of glucosinolate turnover in intact plants. Initiation would be expected to involve hydrolysis of the thioglucoside bond by a myrosinase. In addition to classical TGG myrosinases ( Bones and Rossiter, 2006 ; Wittstock et al., 2016a; b), a number of other myrosinases have been reported in recent years. The
B. vulgaris
genome ( Byrne et al., 2017 ) and transcriptomes ( Wei et al., 2013 ; Zhang et al., 2015 ) were mined for orthologs to genes from
Arabidopsis thaliana
and
Brassica rapa
known or suggested to be involved in glucosinolate turnover in intact plants ( Klein and Sattely, 2017 ), and used to construct a phylogenetic tree ( Fig. 10 ). Two b -glucosidases named “brassininassociated b -glucosidase” (BABG.a and BABG.b) were both suggested to be myrosinases that can activate indole glucosinolates for biosynthesis of the indole phytoalexin brassinin in
B. rapa ( Klein and Sattely, 2017 )
. Interestingly, BABG orthologs are not found in
A. thaliana
while one BABG ortholog was found in the
B. vulgaris
genome on contig 4243. Brassinin is neither known from
A. thaliana
, nor from
B. vulgaris ( Pedras et al., 2015 )
, but only limited investigations have been reported so far. But related non-indole phytoalexins are found in
B. vulgaris
, and their biosynthesis could also involve the BABG paralog.

The myrosinase PEN2 (PENETRATION2) has been found to metabolize indole glucosinolates in
A. thaliana
( Bednarek et al., 2009 ; Clay et al., 2009 ). In
B. rapa
and
A. thaliana
, only one copy of PEN2 has been identified. Likewise, in the
B. vulgaris
genome only one PEN2 ortholog was found; BvPEN2 on pseudomolecule 1. This gene was found to be expressed in rosette leaf transcriptome datasets from both the P- and G-type of
B. vulgaris
( Fig. 10 , Supplementary Table 1 ).

Both the
A. thaliana
and
B. rapa
genomes possess gene(s) annotated as b -glucosidases that form a subgroup that is phylogenetically related to PEN2 and BABG , named BGLU27 ( Klein and Sattely, 2017 ). Expression patterns of BGLU27 were similar to those of BABG ( Klein and Sattely, 2017 ), and a number of BGLU genes in
A. thaliana
have been suggested to code for myrosinases ( Nakano et al., 2017 ). To our knowledge, no BGLU27 has been characterized and any possible function as myrosinases remain to be studied. However, AtBGLU27 (At 3g 60120, published as PEN2-Like1 or PEL-1 ) was strongly induced after
Verticillium longisporum
infection, but indole glucosinolate products were not observed and the effect of a mutation ( pel1 ) was minor ( Iven et al., 2012 ). In
B. vulgaris
, two BGLU27 paralogs were found; BvBGLU27.a and BvBGLU27.b . The BvBGLU27.a gene was localized on the part of the genome currently called pseudomolecule 8 and also found in the rosette leaf transcriptomic dataset from both P and G-type ( Fig. 10 , Supplementary Table 1 ). The other
B. vulgaris
gene, BvBGLU27.b , is localized on pseudomolecule 7 in the genome.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 8. Conversion of spiked ( S )-5-ethyl-5-methylOAT ( 9 ) into 5-ethyl-5-methylOAO ( 10 ) catalyzed by a heat-sensitive catalyst named oxazolidinethionase (OATase) in
Barbarea vulgaris
leaf homogenates (A) and ion trap MS/MS (B) confirmation of the identity of the product 10 (from chromatogram in Fig. 9 E).

Fig. 9. Evidence for conversion of spiked ( S )-5-ethyl-5-methylOAT ( 9 ) into 5-ethyl-5-methylOAO ( 10 ) by a heat-sensitive catalyst in a
B. vulgaris
leaf homogenate. A-D, Total ion chromatograms; E-H, extracted ion chromatograms for specific detection of the OAO product 10 . AþE, extract of native homogenate after incubation (2 h) with spike of 9 dissolved in water; BþF, control extract of homogenate spiked with water; CþG, control similar to AþE but homogenate briefly heated before spike; DþH, control consisting of the same spike as in A and C but incubated in acetate buffer (pH 5, 2 h) in parallel.

subSection.paragraph:
The phylogenetic tree ( Fig. 10 ) suggested that a common ancestor plant species had at least one copy of each of the three gene families; BGLU27 , BABG and PEN2 , and that the AtBABG ortholog was subsequently lost. The clade consisting of the BGLU27 genes has two branches; one including the BGLU27.b genes and one including the BGLU27.a and BGLU27.c genes. Only
B. rapa
has three copies of BGLU27 (a-c), and the phylogenetic analysis suggests a duplication of a common ancestor to the BrBGLU27.a and BrBGLU27.c genes.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 10. Molecular phylogenetic analysis (maximum likelihood) of candidate enzymes for the initial step of glucosinolate turnover in
Barbarea vulgaris
compared to homologs from
Arabidopsis thaliana
and
Brassica rapa
. In protein (enzyme) names, the three species are indicated by the prefixes Bv, At and Br, respectively. Protein sequences for the analysis were deduced from gene sequences. Transcriptomes of two ecotypes of
B. vulgaris
(P-type and G-type) were checked as a supplement to genomic sequences, and an asterisk (*) denote
B. vulgaris
sequences also found in transcriptomes (in each case, sequences were found in both P-type and G-type of the species). The bar represents number of substitutions per site. Only bootstrap values above 70 are shown in the tree.

subSection.paragraph:
The field of glucosinolate turnover in intact plants is in rapid progress ( Nakano et al., 2017 ), and the genes selected for this analysis are only a subset of relevant myrosinase genes. However, the identified genes show that candidates for glucosinolate turnover in intact plants exist in
B. vulgaris
, although the investigated candidates are known as pathogen induced, not constitutive. Clearly, investigations of inducibility of OATase and regulation of candidate myrosinases would be relevant for assessing the suggested involvement of OATase in glucosinolate turnover. Although PEN2 and GLU27 are known as pathogen inducible genes, expression of the
B. vulgaris
paralogs was detected in the
B. vulgaris
transcriptomes ( Fig. 10 ). Ring-opening by hydrolysis of either the ester-like or amide-like motives in resedine is a potential further step in turnover.

In conclusion, resedine is formed from barbarin by a heat sensitive catalyst in crushed parts of
B. vulgaris
,
N. of fi cinale
and
R. luteola
, but is not detectable in intact plants. As
N. of fi cinale
is a vegetable often eaten raw, resedine will be part of human nutrition in the USA where watercress containing glucobarbarin is marketed ( Agerbirk et al., 2014 ). We anticipate the catalyst to be an enzyme, OATase, constitutively expressed in a variety of tissues for turnover of barbarin formed in vivo . The product resedine exists in two enantiomeric forms. During review of this manuscript, chiral separation of the enantiomers was achieved, and it was found that essentially one enantiomer is formed during autolysis in G-type
B. vulgaris
, further supporting enzymatic formation from ( R )-barbarin (T. Yang and Agerbirk, unpublished).

Regulation of the OATase is likely but was not tested. The reaction could be simply a detoxification involved in glucosinolate turnover, possibly allowing sulfur recycling ( Maruyama-Nakashita, 2017 ). Considering the range of bioactivities of other known OAOs, the reaction could also be involved in defense ( Van Leur et al., 2008 ), signaling ( Malinowski et al., 2017 ) or biosynthesis. Biosynthesis of non-indole phytoalexins starting from phenethyl glucosinolates in
B. vulgaris
and
N. of fi cinale
has already been suggested ( Pedras and To, 2014 ; Pedras et al., 2015 ). As the enzyme activity was detected in two plant families, it could be a widespread enzyme involved in turnover of OATs in the Brassicales . Detoxification of contaminating OATs in cruciferous protein would be a potential industrial application of such an enzyme.

Elemental composition and UV spectral data so far constitute the only documentation to support formation of the hypothetic thioamide product “ 5 ” from glucobarbarin (Austin et al., 1068a). However, the general formation of thioamides is better documented ( Austin et al., 1968b ). Austin et al. (1968a) reported high yields of thioamide from b -hydroxylated glucosinolates but lack of thioamide from a non-hydroxylated glucosinolate, and suggested a mechanism of formation involving the hydroxy group. These authors reported 40% molar yield of the thioamide from epiprogoitrin. However, later authors ( Bellostas et al., 2008 ) reported around tenfold lower yield (and the identification of the thioamide was not conclusive). Furthermore, analytical evidence (GC-MS and comparison with an authentic reference) was recently reported for formation of the thioamide from a glucosinolate lacking a hydroxy group (3-methoxybenzylglucosinolate) ( Stevens et al., 2009 ). Hence, formation of thioamides as such from glucosinolates is decently documented, but any influence of the b -hydroxy group is not. Furthermore, the apparently consistent high yields in the pioneering papers ( Austin et al., 1968a ; b) contrast with the findings of later authors. It seems as if yet unidentified factors influence the possible formation of thioamides from non-enzymatic, ferrous ion catalyzed breakdown of glucosinolates. As the disulfide of thioglucose has been reported to accompany general ferrous ion catalyzed nitrile formation ( Youngs and Perlin, 1967 ), and as we detected amide formation under such conditions as well, a complex reaction involving various other sulfur compounds could be hypothesized. From the perspective of glucobarbarin biology, the results reported here show that formation of a suggested thioamide from glucobarbarin is not easily reproduced and was apparently not of importance at a range of biologically relevant conditions. The latter result had been predicted in a review article ( Bones and Rossiter, 2006 ).

The genus
Barbarea
seems to have lost aliphatic glucosinolates and gained diversification of phenethyl and indole glucosinolates and derived compounds ( Olsen et al., 2016 ). The increasingly wellcharacterized wild plant
B. vulgaris ( Byrne et al., 2017 )
is polymorphic for a range of defense related metabolites as well as pest- and disease resistances ( Badenes-Perez and Lopez-Perez, 2018 ). This biochemically innovative plant species would seem to be a valuable genetic resource for a number of traits, including some pathways of glucosinolate turnover and phytoalexin biosynthesis as discussed here.

Seeds of the G-type of
Barbarea vulgaris R. Br.
( Brassicaceae ) were of accession B44, using a batch propagated by the author NA in 2008 ( Agerbirk et al., 2003 ). The plants used for the experiments were grown in loamy soil in a sunny garden, and were large second year plants with fresh, healthy-looking upper leaves and green siliques. Seeds of the analyzed plants have been deposited at Nordgen (www.nordgen.org/sesto), publicly available with accession number NGB31789. Samples for the experiments described here were taken in April‾ June 2017 and transported and stored in plastic bags until use later the same day. Due to lack of additional seeds of the same accession, seeds of
B. vulgaris
(G-type) were from the accession Hedeland 2010 ( Heimes et al., 2016 ).
Reseda luteola
L. ( Resedaceae ) plants were from the permanent plant collection at Dept. of Plant and Environmental Sciences, KU, and the identity confirmed from morphology by NA. Fresh, green branches with leaves were harvested from flowering plants in June 2017 and transported in plastic bags until dissection into leaves and shoot axes about 1 h later. Seeds of
R. luteola
and
Reseda odorata
L. ( Resedaceae ) were from Chiltern Seeds, Wallingford, UK .

GSLs were determined directly or as desulfated derivatives (“desulfoGSL method”). HPLC-DAD of intact GSLs was carried out using eluents acidified with CF 3 COOH at 0.1%, exactly as previously described ( Agerbirk and Olsen, 2012 ). For logistic reasons, some routine control of GSL hydrolysis was carried out using formic acid at the same concentration (0.1%), giving increased tailing but still sufficiently sharp peaks for integration. The desulfoGSL method was carried out in two laboratories at slightly different conditions. In the Bologna lab for isolation work, conditions were as reported by Pagnotta et al. (2017) . In the Copenhagen lab, for determination of GSL profiles of
Reseda species
, ion trap HPLC-MS/MS analysis after enzymatic desulfation was carried out as reported by Olsen et al. (2016) .

paragraph.emphasis: 3.4. Myrosinase-catalyzed glucosinolate hydrolysis in vitro using isolated components

subSection.paragraph:
The GSL (24 nmol, 0.15 mM final conc.) and myrosinase (from
Sinapis alba , Sigma, T
4528) (72 M g, 30 mU) were dissolved in 60 mM aq. sodium acetate pH 5 with added ascorbic acid (5 mM) and either with or without FeSO 4 (2.5 mM). Each reaction mixture was incubated at ambient temperature (20 ǫC ) overnight in a total of 160 M l. An aliquot was taken, MeOH added to 20%, the mixture was centrifuged and tested by HPLC-DAD for confirmation of complete disappearance of intact GSL, and for hydrolysis products by ion trap HPLC-MS (Section 3.6.).

Glucobarbarin (3 M mol, 15 mM final conc.) was incubated for 22 h in 150 mM aq. (NH 4 ) 2 Fe(SO 4 ) 2 , 45 mM sodium acetate buffer pH 5, in a total of 200 M l. A rust-red precipitate was observed. A sample (30 M l) of the liquid phase was taken after incubation, diluted tenfold with 20% MeOH, centrifuged and analyzed by HPLC for intact GSLs, confirming extensive glucobarbarin degradation. The extent of degradation was calculated from peak areas, comparing with an aliquot of intact glucobarbarin stock not subjected to the ferrous salt and diluted in parallel to the ferrous-salt treated aliquot. The same sample was analyzed by HPLC-DAD, searching at 210 nm and 267 nm for the hypothetic thioamide “ 5 ”. For further analysis and peak isolation, the remaining 170 M l was repeatedly extracted with ethyl acetate. The organic phase was evaporated and the residue dissolved in 800 M l 20% aq. MeOH and centrifuged. The supernatant was analyzed and two dominant peaks ( 4 and 8 , Fig. 5 ) and four tiny peaks isolated by HPLC-DAD (Section 3.8). The entire organic fraction and the collected peaks were analyzed by ion trap HPLC-MS for identification and search for “ 5 ”. The two major peaks, 4 and 8 , were also subjected to HPLCQqToF-MS. The experiments were carried out in March 2017 , before the handling of
B. vulgaris
homogenates and of H 2 O 2 described in subsequent sections. Likewise, other oxidative reagents were not handled in the laboratory in parallel.

heading.emphasis: 3.6. Determination of glucobarbarin products by ion trap HPLC-MS

subSection.paragraph:
Ion trap HPLC-MS/MS of hydrolysis products from glucobarbarin was carried out using a C18 column and a Bruker HCT-Ultra ion trap detector as previously reported ( Agerbirk et al., 2014 ; Agerbirk and Olsen, 2015), except that the ion trap settings were adjusted for increased sensitivity and MS2 fragmentation of the relevant m / z range (target mass,
180 m
/ z ; precursor selection,100‾
300 m
/ z ; scan range 100‾
400 m
/ z ) (Supplementary Fig. 5D ), that UV data were collected (sum of absorption from 190 to 700 nm as well as DAD spectra) and that the eluent A and gradient were slightly modified. The mobile phases were: A, water with 0.1% (v/v) HCOOH and 10 M M NaCl; B, acetonitrile with 0.1% (v/v) HCOOH. The gradient program was: 0‾1 min, isocratic 2% B; 1‾8 min, linear gradient 2%‾ 40% B; 8‾9 min, linear gradient 40%‾90% B; 9 to 11.5 isocratic 90% B; 11.60‾14 min, isocratic 2% B. The flow rate was generally 0.2 ml/ min but was increased to 0.3 ml/min between 11.5 and 13.5 min.

The relative levels of 2 , 3 , 4 and 8 were calculated from peak intensities at the relevant retention time in extracted ion chromatograms of the major ions in each spectrum, i.e. m / z 202, 180, 164, 120 ( 2 , tR 8.0 min), m / z 186, 164, 146, 120 ( 3 , tR 7.0 min), m / z 170, 148, 130 ( 4 , tR 6.4 min), and m / z 188 ( 8 , tR 4.3 min), taking reduced molar detector response of the nitrile 4 into account by dividing the peak intensity with 0.11 and of the amide 8 by dividing the peak intensity with 0.64 (Section 3.7). Considering the similar structures of 2 and 3 , their MS-detector responses were assumed to be equal when all four major ions above were integrated, in accordance with observed stable total concentration of the two ( Fig. 7B ).

heading.emphasis: 3.7. Detector calibration for nitrile and amide products

subSection.paragraph: The molar UV-detector response of the nitrile 4 derived from 2 was calculated from the increase of the nitrile peak and the decrease of the barbarin peak in HPLC-DAD, both at 210 nm , in controlled hydrolysis experiments with and without added FeSO 4 . The molar peak area of the nitrile 4 was on average 51% of the molar peak area of barbarin, both at 210 nm , allowing calculation of levels of the nitrile in simple samples based on the barbarin standard curve and this factor. For complex samples, HPLC-MS analysis was needed, and this analysis was calibrated with the same sample used for UV calibration ( Fig. 3 ). The molar MS detector response of the nitrile 4 base peak ( m / z 130) was on average 15% of the response of the barbarin base peak ( m / z 180). Combining all major MS peaks to obtain increased sensitivity ( m / z 170, 148 and 130 for 4 , and m / z 202, 180, 146 and 120 for 2 ), the molar MS detector response of 4 was 11% of the molar detector response of 2 .

The MS detector response of 3-hydroxy-3-phenylpropaneamide ( 8 ) was estimated from comparison of HPLC-DAD and HPLC-MS of a mixed sample ( Fig. 5B ), assuming equal UV response of 4 and 8 at 210 nm . In this way, the molar response of the amide ( m / z 188 trace) was estimated to approximately 64% of the detector response of 2 (combining m / z traces 202, 180, 146 and 120).

paragraph.emphasis: 3.8. HPLC-DAD of glucobarbarin products and isolation of breakdown products due to a ferrous salt

subSection.paragraph: Hydrolysis products in 20% aq. MeOH were separated by HPLC-DAD ( Agerbirk et al., 2014 ). Briefly, the column had a phenylhexyl stationary phase and we used a 2 min isocratic period with 100% H 2 O followed by a 48 min linear gradient over from 0 to 70% MeOH. The injection volume was 100 M l. UV-data from 210 to 370 nm were collected, and chromatograms at specific detection wavelengths prepared according to the analyte searched for ( 210 nm for 2 , 3 , 4 , hypothetic “ 5 ”, and 8 ; 267 nm for hypothetic 5 ; 240 nm for 2 ). For identification of products of ferrous salt catalyzed breakdown, peaks of 4 and 8 collected from two consecutive runs were pooled and analyzed by ion trap HPLC-MS and HPLC-QqToF-MS.

Isolated products and crude synthesis samples in H 2 O or 20% aq. MeOH were analyzed by liquid chromatography coupled to quadrupole time-of-flight mass spectrometry. A Dionex UltiMate™ 3000 RS UPLC system from Thermo Scientific™ (Waltham, MA USA ) was used and equipped with a Kinetex XB-C18 column ( 2.1 mm × 100 mm , 1.7 M m, Phenomenex). The injection volume was 5 M l. Mobile phase A was MilliQ water with 0.05% formic acid, whereas mobile phase B was acetonitrile with 0.05% formic acid. The 20 min stepwise linear gradient was t ¼ 0 min, 2% B; t ¼ 10 min, 60% B; t ¼ 12 min, 60% B; t ¼ 13 min, 2% B; t ¼ 20 min, 2% B. The flow rate was 0.3 ml/min. For detection, a Bruker Compact QqToF mass spectrometer ( Bremen , Germany ) was used and operated in positive mode. The MS settings were: dry temperature 220 ǫC , dry gas flow rate 8 l/min, capillary 4000 V, collision energy 7 eV and collision RF 500 Vpp, transfer time 100 M s, pre-pulse storage 5 M s. The Qq-ToF was operated with mass range set from
50 to 1200 m
/ z and was calibrated with sodium formate clusters at the beginning of every injection. Acquisition of LC‾MS data was performed in Bruker DataAnalysis 4.3.

Leaves or siliques ( 0.5 g fresh weight, rinsed with a brush for any macroscopic impurities) were weighed accurately and homogenized in a porcelain mortar and the total homogenate transferred to a 20 ml glass beaker with lid. The homogenate was incubated at ambient temperature (20‾25 ǫC ) at the intended autolysis time. For experimental variation of conditions, individual assays were incubated in parallel but slightly displaced for logistic reasons. After the intended autolysis time, the beaker was put on a hot-plate and 8 ml of preheated, boiling 20% aq. MeOH was added for boiling extraction for 1 min (moving beaker on and off to avoid vigorous boiling), followed by centrifugation ( 4000 g , 5 min). The supernatant was added solvent to 10.0 ml in a volumetric cylinder followed by mixing. A 1.4 ml sample was taken for freezing (–20 ǫC ) overnight (for settling of any debris), thawed and subjected to additional centrifugation ( 6000 g , 3 min). The resulting sample was suitable for HPLC-DAD analysis ( Agerbirk et al., 2014 ), used for some samples (Suppl. Figs. 2A ‾C) but not reported quantitatively. Before HPLC-MS, used for all reported quantitative results, a further 5.00 fold dilution in 20% aq. MeOH was done. For other plant parts, seeds and seedlings, lower fresh weight was used resulting in lower sensitivity, and for seeds water was added during homogenization ( Table 1 ).

For the experiment reported in Fig. 7B, a combined leaf homogenate was first allowed to autolyze (0.3 h) for formation of barbarin, during which time the homogenate was distributed in six similar 0.50 g aliquots in beakers. Each aliquot was mixed with 3.0 ml sodium phosphate buffer (0.1 M, pH 7), then incubated for a total of 25 h. During this incubation, the aliquots were subjected to brief (1 min) boiling at various times. The samples were boiled (pairwise) after either 0.3 h, 6.3 h or 24.3 h, followed by continued incubation until usual hot extraction of all portions after 25 h and preparation for ion trap HPLC-MS analysis as in the general protocol.

Pooled extracts (30 ml) of crushed upper leaves and siliques (in total 2 g fresh wt.) of
B. vulgaris
, allowed to autolyze for 24 h, were concentrated to 8 ml under a gentle air-stream to remove MeOH and simplify loading. Two solid phase extraction cartridges (Supelclean C 18, 500 mg , Supelco) were activated, each with 3 ml MeOH, and equilibrated with 3 ml H 2 O. The extract was split in two and loaded on the cartridges, which were each eluted stepwise with 3 ml each of 10% aq. MeOH, 20% aq. MeOH, 70% aq. MeOH, 100% aq. MeOH. Resedine ( 3 ) and 2 were both found in the 70% MeOH fraction. This fraction was concentrated under a gentle air stream until near dryness, and brought to 3 ml of 20% aq. MeOH. Resedine was isolated by repeated prep. HPLC from this fraction, using the usual HPLC equipment ( Agerbirk and Olsen, 2011 ) (Supplementary Fig. 2 ) fitted with a ‘Luna’ phenylhexyl column ( 25 cm × 4.6 mm , 5 M m) (Phenomenex, Torrance, CA, USA ). The injection volume was 400 M l. After 2 min at 100% H 2 O, a linear gradient in MeCN was applied, from 0 to 35% in 28 min, followed by a brief wash and equilibration in H 2 O. Resedine eluted at 22 min, a few min after a group of numerous other peaks, while 2 eluted at 32 min. Resedine for NMR was obtained by freeze drying after partial evaporation under a gentle air stream. The proton NMR spectrum of resedine was recorded on an AVANCE III 600 spectrometer equipped with a TCI cryoprobe. The sample was dissolved in CDCl 3 and the temperature set at 298 K during data acquisition. The spectrum was referenced at 7.26 ppm for the residual protonated signal. PERCH spectral analysis started with the building of a 3D model of the resedine molecular structure by means of MMS, the modeling tool integrated in PERCH. The predicted chemical shift and coupling constant values inferred from the 3D model were iteratively refined so that the corresponding calculated spectrum matched at best the experimental one ( Laatikainen et al., 1996 ).

heading.emphasis: 3.12. Synthetic conversion of oxazolidine-2-thiones into oxazolidin- 2-ones

subSection.paragraph:
Conversion of OATs to OAOs by treatment with H 2 O 2 had been reported ( Evans and Weber, 1987 ; Moreno-Ma nas ~ and Padros, 1993 ). Synthesis of 3 was conducted by incubation of 2 (20 M M) in up to 8% aq. H 2 O 2 overnight. We observed complete conversion of 2 into resedine ( 3 ) (CAS 7693-77-8) and a more polar product (around 1:1 judged from HPLC-DAD area at 210 nm ). Moderate variation of the conditions, with [H 2 O 2 ] ranging from 0.8 to 8% and reaction times ranging from 4 h to 18 h (N ¼ 5), had no significant effect on product profile ( Fig. 11 ). The intended product was found identical to 3 from
B. vulgaris
and
R. luteola
by ion trap HPLC-MS/ MS. Using QqToF-MS we confirmed the molecular formula (found: 164.0704 [MþH] þ , calculated for C 9 H 10 O 2 N: 164.0706. From QqToF-MS we also confirmed that the major fragments were due to loss of H 2 O and CO 2 (Supplementary Fig. 7 ). The more polar product was tentatively identified as 2-amino-1-phenylethanol, a previously suggested breakdown product of barbarin ( Lutfullin et al., 1976 ), by ion trap HPLC-MS/MS (Supplementary Fig. 7 ) and HPLC-QqToF-MS (found: 138.0913 [MþH] þ , calculated for C 8 H 12 ON þ : 138.0913; found: 120.0804 [M-H 2 OþH] þ , calculated for C 8 H 10 N þ : 120.0808). Exclusive formation of the proton adduct, not the sodium adduct, supported an amine functional group, and loss of water in MS2 supported a hydroxyl group.

Two other OATs were available, ( S )-5-ethyl-5-methylOAT ( 9 ) and ( R )-5-vinylOAT (( R )-goitrin) ( 11 ). For use as references below, they were also converted into OAOs by incubation overnight with aq. 1% H 2 O 2 . The identity of the authentic reactant 9 was confirmed by ion trap HPLC-MS/MS, m / z 146 [MþH] þ (with major loss of H 2 S in MS2), m / z 168 [MþNa] þ , and high res. HPLC-MS/MS (found: 146.0637, calculated for C 6 H 12 NOS þ : 146.0634). The major product 5-methyl-5-ethylOAO ( 10 ) was tentatively identified in ion trap HPLC-MS: m / z 130 [MþH] þ (with major loss of H 2 O in MS2), m / z 152 [MþNa] þ and high res. HPLC-MS (found: 130.0867, calculated for C 6 H 12 NO
2 þ
: 130.0863) (Supplementary Fig. 8 ).

Likewise, the identity of the authentic reactant 11 was confirmed by ion trap HPLC-MS/MS and high res. HPLC-MS/MS (found: 130.0318, calculated for C 5 H 8 NOS þ : 130.0321). The major product 5-vinylOAO ( 12 ) was tentatively identified in ion trap HPLC-MS: m / z 114 [MþH] þ , m / z 136 [MþNa] þ and high res HPLC-MS (found: 114.0546, calculated for C 5 H 8 NO
2 þ
: 114.0550) (Supplementary Fig. 9 ). For these latter OAO syntheses, the corresponding amino-alcohols were apparently not major side-products of the oxidative conversion from OAT to OAO by H 2 O 2 , but other polar side-products were detected.

For each experiment, a number of
B. vulgaris
upper leaves (4‾8) were pooled and homogenized (in a mortar at room temperature) in order to minimize biological variation between individual assays. For testing of various OAO precursors, four 0.10 g aliquots of leaf homogenate were distributed in each of four 10 ml beakers, mixed with 0.10 ml of either water (control), aq. ( R )-goitrin ( 4 mg /ml), aq. epiprogoitrin ( 8 mg /ml) or aq. ( S )-5-ethyl-5-methylOAT ( 4 mg /ml). In a further four beakers, water and the same potential substrate solutions were mixed 1:1 with 50 mM aq. sodium acetate buffer pH 5 as a control, and also incubated in parallel. After gentle mixing with a pipette tip, each beaker was covered with a lid and incubated in parallel for 2 h. Then, beakers were put on a hot-plate, 2 ml boiling water was added, and hot extraction carried out for 1 min. This experiment was carried out in duplicate on two different days, except for the epiprogoitrin experiment that was not repeated.

For testing heat sensitivity, half of the total leaf homogenate was heated for 4 min in a test tube immersed in a boiling water bath. From the heated part, four 0.10 g aliquots were distributed in each of four 10 ml beakers, mixed with either 0.10 ml aq. ( S )-5-ethyl-5- methylOAT ( 4 mg /ml) (N ¼ 2) or 0.10 ml water (control) (N ¼ 2). From the remaining, non-heated part, four 0.10 g aliquots were also distributed in four beakers and added the same amounts of the OAT solution or water (N ¼ 2 þ 2). In a further four beakers, the same OAT solution or water was mixed 1:1 with 50 mM aq. sodium acetate buffer as a control, and also incubated in parallel (N ¼ 2 þ 2). After gentle mixing with a pipette tip, each beaker was covered with a lid and incubated in parallel for 2 h. Then, beakers were put on a hot-plate, 2 ml boiling water was added, and hot extraction carried out for 1 min.

From both experiments, the entire material after boiling extraction was taken to 2.0 ml and mixed. A sample was centrifuged ( 6000 g , 4 min) and the supernatant taken to ion trap HPLC-MS analysis. Care was taken in all experiments to make sure that H 2 O 2 contamination could be completely ruled out as a factor. Analysis of enzyme assay products was carried out before analysis of OAO references containing surplus H 2 O 2 to make sure that contamination with H 2 O 2 could not happen in the HPLC autosampler either. Lack of OAO production from homogenate alone, observation of barbarin and resedine as endogenous metabolites (also in heated control due to reaction before heating), and positive OAO production from ( S )-5-ethyl-5-methylOAT, goitrin, and progoitrin were all consistent.

The
B. vulgaris
G-type genome ( Byrne et al. 2017 ) and transcriptome ( Wei et al. 2013 ) and P-type transcriptome ( Zhang et al. 2015 ) were mined using genes previously described by Klein and Sattely (2017) . The sequences were collected from Phytozome (https://phytozome.jgi.doe.gov/pz/portal.html):
Arabidopsis thaliana
(At 1g 47600, At 2g 44490, At 3g 60120);
Brassica rapa
(Brara.E00435, Brara.E00428, Brara.I04143, Brara.D02695, Brara.E00436, Brara.D00184 (truncated version, so we used XM 009140622.1 from NCBI). The sequences found in the
B. vulgaris
genome have not yet received a GeneID, but are available as supplementary data with this paper.

Nucleotide sequences of the candidate genes from
B. vulgaris
and the collection of genes from
A. thaliana
and
B. rapa
(Supplementary Table 1 ) were analyzed in MEGA6 ( Tamura et al. 2013 ). Intron/exon structures from
B. vulgaris
genomic candidate genes were predicted by comparison with
B. vulgaris
transcripts or
A. thaliana
homologs. Protein sequences of the candidate genes from the
B. vulgaris
G-type genome and the collection of genes from
A. thaliana
and
B. rapa
were aligned using Muscle and standard parameters in MEGA6 ( Tamura et al. 2013 ). Due to different sequence length, the phylogenetic analysis was constructed based on position 170 to position 563 in the amino acid residue alignment (Supplementary Table 2). The phylogenetic tree ( Fig. 10 ) was inferred by using the Maximum Likelihood method based on the JTT matrix-based model ( Jones et al. 1992 ). The tree with the highest log likelihood (–3049.6303) is shown. Initial tree(s) for the heuristic search were obtained automatically by applying Neighbor-Join and BioNJ algorithms to a matrix of pairwise distances estimated using a JTT model, and then selecting the topology with superior log likelihood value. A discrete Gamma distribution was used to model evolutionary rate differences among sites (5 categories) (þG, parameter ¼ 0.6003).

Conceived study: NA, CM, LL, PR. Did HPLC-MS incl. optimization: AM, EL, NA. Did and interpreted NMR: JMN. Isolated glucosinolates and provided non-
Barbarea
OATs: LU, SC, LL. Did bioinformatics: PØE supervised by SB and NA. Did remaining experiments, interpreted MS and noticed resedine: NA. Wrote draft: NA. Wrote paper: All.
